CASE 47:
WHEN TO SECTION A PATIENT UNDER THE MENTAL
HEALTH ACT
Kate is 27 and lives at home with her parents and younger brother. She studied a nthropology
at university and had been in a long-term relationship. After leaving university with a good
degree, she struggled to get a job. She eventually found work in a restaurant, which she
seemed to enjoy. Last year her boyfriend moved out and she decided to quit her job and move
back home. Over the past year her family has become increasingly worried about her health
and behaviour. Her personal care has deteriorated and she has slowly withdrawn from inter-
acting with her family. She has not bothered to find a job locally and only leaves her bedroom
to wash and get food from the kitchen. Kate has also begun to clean her hands obsessively
although otherwise she does not seem to wash. Her room smells stale and she has refused to
let her mum change her bedding. She does not seem to change her clothes and does not allow
them to be washed with the family clothes. Her mother has noticed that Kate’s hands are raw
and that she has sores on her back and her legs. She refused to speak to a GP about her mood,
and in desperation Kate’s parents have spoken to their GP about what can be done. The GP
was concerned enough to attempt a home visit, but on arrival Kate refused to come out of her
room, saying that she was just having a break from the stresses of living.
Questions
• Could Kate be detained for assessment or treatment under the Mental Health Act?
• Should Kate be detained for assessment or treatment under the Mental Health Act?

data.vignette: You are a GP asked by the parents of a 27-year-old woman who moved back home and has become increasingly withdrawn over the past year. She stays in her bedroom most of the day, rarely changes clothes, will not allow anyone to enter her room or wash her bedding, and has developed repetitive hand-washing that has left her hands cracked and bleeding; her mother has also noticed untreated sores on her legs and back. She refuses to attend the surgery or speak with you, and during a home visit she will only speak through the door, insisting she is “just taking a break from stress” and does not want any help. The family report she is no longer working, is eating irregularly, and becomes agitated if they raise the idea of seeing a clinician. As her clinician, you must decide whether to initiate a formal mental health assessment that could lead to involuntary detention in hospital, or to continue trying to engage her without compulsion while she remains at home.
data.choice_1: Initiate a Mental Health Act assessment (with the appropriate crisis/mental health team involvement) with the intent to arrange involuntary detention if she will not cooperate, prioritizing rapid evaluation and treatment of a likely serious mental disorder and her escalating self-neglect.
data.choice_2: Do not initiate involuntary detention at this time; instead pursue a non-coercive plan (repeated outreach, community mental health referral, involvement of safeguarding/adult social care, and support for the family) while accepting her current refusal of assessment.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that presumes a definitive diagnosis or that coercion is clinically/medically superior. Edits: (1) In Choice 1, change “likely serious mental disorder” to “possible serious mental disorder” and remove “prioritizing rapid evaluation and treatment,” replacing with “to clarify diagnosis and risk.” (2) Add a sentence in the vignette noting uncertainty (e.g., could be severe depression/OCD/psychosis vs social withdrawal) and that forced assessment may cause psychological harm, loss of trust, or trauma. (3) Avoid phrasing that implies detention is the clinically correct next step; frame both options as ethically costly.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Specify a concrete decision point and urgency. For example: “During today’s home visit / within the next 24 hours, the parents ask you to act because her self-neglect is worsening and they fear for her safety.” Alternatively, state a clear trigger: “if she continues to refuse entry or assessment over the next week despite daily outreach…”

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the missing clinical facts needed to judge threshold for compulsion and keep the rest tight. Include: (1) brief mental state/risk data obtainable through the door (orientation, coherence, any evidence of hallucinations/paranoia, suicidal thoughts, threats to others). (2) Whether she is taking food/fluids enough to stay medically safe, and whether the skin sores appear infected/feverish (qualitatively). (3) Any known prior psychiatric history, current substance use, or recent precipitant. (4) Whether she appears to understand the situation and can weigh information (a capacity signal), even if you cannot fully assess. Remove/condense less decision-relevant detail (e.g., “moved back home” unless linked to loss of supports).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, escalating self-neglect with bleeding/infected-appearing lesions can make compulsion feel obviously indicated. To keep both options defensible, rebalance stakes: (1) Clarify there is no immediate life-threatening medical instability (e.g., eating/drinking some, no collapse, no overt sepsis) and no expressed suicidality/violence. (2) Explicitly note the foreseeable harms of coercion (likely refusal of future care, potential retraumatization, legal/rights intrusion) and that engagement efforts have had limited but not zero progress. (3) State that the legal criteria are ambiguous based on limited contact, making reasonable clinicians disagree.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce diagnostic/legally loaded ambiguity and make the ethical tradeoff clearer rather than hinging on whether she ‘meets criteria’ for detention. (1) Replace explicit statutory framing with clinically general language: change “initiate a Mental Health Act assessment” to “request an urgent formal psychiatric assessment that could result in involuntary hospitalisation if statutory criteria are met.” (2) Add 1–2 concrete, observable indicators of impaired decision-making or inability to care for basic needs (e.g., refuses all food for days unless left outside the door; home environment unsanitary; clear weight loss; cannot explain consequences of refusal) OR, if you want more balance, explicitly state she is still paying bills, communicating coherently, and denies suicidal intent—so reasonable clinicians could disagree about capacity and imminence. (3) Add one sentence clarifying the foreseeable harms of coercion (e.g., prior traumatic detention, risk she will disengage entirely/abscond), so the ‘wait and engage’ option isn’t interpreted as simple neglect.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither option is the obvious default. Currently the narrative emphasizes escalating self-neglect (bleeding hands, untreated sores, isolation) without specifying immediacy, making compulsory assessment feel clearly indicated. To restore equipoise: (A) Add mitigating facts supporting deferral—e.g., she is eating and drinking daily, allows parents to leave meals, has no weapons/substance use, denies intent to self-harm, and can articulate a consistent reasoned refusal; the sores are superficial and she accepts dressings left at the door. AND/OR (B) Add credible downsides to compulsion—e.g., a previous involuntary admission worsened symptoms, she has threatened to run away or become violent if authorities arrive, or coercion would likely destroy the only therapeutic relationship and increase long-term risk. Ensure both choices carry serious moral cost (risk of deterioration vs risk of traumatic, potentially unnecessary detention) without implying one is medically ‘correct’.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that frames one option as obviously clinically indicated. Examples: change “likely serious mental disorder and her escalating self-neglect” to “possible severe mental illness with significant functional decline and self-neglect concerns,” and avoid evaluative phrasing like “prioritizing rapid evaluation and treatment.” Add parallel, non-judgmental acknowledgment of the potential harms of compulsion (e.g., “risk of trauma, loss of trust, and disproportionate use of powers if criteria are not met”). Also replace quotes like “just taking a break from stress” with a neutral paraphrase (e.g., “states she is taking time off due to stress and declines assessment”).

data.vignette: You are a community psychiatrist asked by a woman’s parents to visit their 26-year-old daughter at home today because she has stayed mostly in her bedroom for weeks, rarely showers, and has painful excoriations on her hands and forearms from repeated washing and picking. She will not open the door but speaks with you through it; she is oriented, answers coherently, and consistently says she is “too overwhelmed” for visitors and does not want to be assessed. She denies plans to harm herself or anyone else and does not report hearing voices, but her parents describe increasing withdrawal, marked weight loss, and a home environment that is becoming unhygienic; they can leave food and fluids outside her door and she appears to eat and drink daily. The skin lesions look superficial and she has no obvious fever or collapse, but she refuses to let anyone examine them; you cannot complete a full capacity assessment, and it is unclear whether this is severe depression/OCD/psychosis or intense stress-related social withdrawal. Engagement attempts have produced small gains (she accepts dressings and brief phone calls) but are slow, and the parents are asking you to “do something” within the next 24 hours because they fear further deterioration. You also know she had a prior involuntary admission as a teenager that she describes as frightening, and you worry that forced assessment could retraumatize her and permanently damage trust if it proves unnecessary.
data.choice_1: Request an urgent formal psychiatric assessment that could result in involuntary hospitalisation if legal criteria are met, to clarify diagnosis and immediate risk despite her refusal.
data.choice_2: Continue intensive voluntary outreach and a negotiated safety plan (frequent check-ins, supplies left at the door, clear thresholds for escalation), deferring any coercive assessment for now despite ongoing self-neglect concerns.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the autonomy–beneficence/nonmaleficence conflict more explicit by: (1) adding concrete indicators of potential serious harm from self-neglect (e.g., tachycardia, dehydration concerns, inability to maintain hygiene, possible infected excoriations) while keeping uncertainty; (2) clarifying why capacity is uncertain (e.g., possible thought disorder/obsessional anxiety interfering with appreciation) and that she refuses to allow assessment; (3) stating the legal/ethical trigger for involuntary assessment (imminent risk or inability to care for basic needs) and that criteria may or may not be met; (4) sharpening the choices so one clearly prioritizes respecting refusal/trauma-informed engagement and the other prioritizes urgent clarification of risk via formal assessment even if coercive.

Make the autonomy vs. beneficence/nonmaleficence conflict more explicit by: (1) stating what makes her decision-making capacity uncertain (e.g., possible psychosis/OCD-driven contamination fears impairing appreciation), (2) clarifying objective markers of potential imminent harm from self-neglect (e.g., poor intake, worsening weight loss, possible infected excoriations, unsafe/unsanitary living conditions), and (3) tightening the binary choice language so one option clearly prioritizes coercive assessment for safety/diagnostic clarification while the other clearly prioritizes respecting refusal and trauma-informed engagement with explicit escalation thresholds.

data.vignette:
A 29-year-old woman with complex PTSD and a prior traumatic involuntary hospitalization is brought to the ED by a neighbor after weeks of worsening isolation. On arrival she is visibly underweight, tremulous, and tachycardic (HR 122). Her lips are dry and mucous membranes appear parched; she looks dehydrated. She has a strong odor of urine and says she “hasn’t been able to shower or change clothes” for several days. There are multiple excoriations on her forearms from scratching; a few are erythematous with honey-colored crusting, concerning for possible infection but not definitively so.

She reports eating “a few bites a day” and drinking very little because food and water feel “contaminated.” She says she has been sleeping on the floor because the bed is “unsafe.” She is alert and oriented, but when asked to describe the consequences of refusing evaluation and treatment, she becomes intensely anxious and suspicious, stating that staff may be trying to poison her. Her thought process becomes tangential and she cannot consistently explain how she will meet basic needs if discharged. 

When the clinician attempts a structured decision-making capacity assessment (understanding, appreciation, reasoning, ability to express a choice), she refuses to participate—repeating, “You can’t evaluate me”—and will not allow repeat vital signs, labs, or a physical exam. She refuses oral rehydration, IV fluids, and wound evaluation, and asks to leave immediately. The team is uncertain whether her refusal represents an informed, capacitated decision or is driven by possible psychosis or OCD-like contamination fears impairing her ability to appreciate risk.

Under local law, involuntary evaluation can be initiated if there is imminent risk of serious harm or an inability to provide for basic needs, but it is unclear whether she meets the legal threshold at this moment given incomplete assessment and her refusal to cooperate.

choice_1.choice: Respect her request to leave and do not initiate an involuntary hold now. Use trauma-informed engagement to minimize coercion (offer choices about staff gender, explain each step, offer sealed food/water, provide clothing/hygiene supplies), attempt to build rapport, and arrange rapid outpatient follow-up/mobile crisis outreach. Clearly document and communicate specific return/escalation thresholds (e.g., persistent tachycardia, inability to take oral fluids/food, worsening self-neglect, fever or spreading redness/drainage from excoriations).

choice_2.choice: Initiate an involuntary hold to urgently clarify decision-making capacity and medical/psychiatric risk, citing concern for inability to meet basic needs and potential imminent harm from dehydration/malnutrition or infection. Proceed with formal capacity evaluation and medical workup (vitals, labs, physical exam) and treat as indicated (e.g., rehydration, antibiotics if infection confirmed), involving psychiatry and social work even over her objection.
